newsitem.title: UK: BA calls for meeting with cabin crew union.
newsitem.headline: BA calls for meeting with cabin crew union.

text.p: British Airways Plc said on Monday it had invited BASSA, its biggest cabin crew union, to meet today to table union proposals on how to achieve the 42 million pounds ($70.5 million) savings wanted in a pay restructuring dispute.
"The purpose of the meeting is to receive and clarify the proposals so we can subsequently evaluate the details they put forward," BA chief executive Bob Ayling said in a statement.

The need for a target of 42 million pounds, part of the 1.0 billion pounds savings and increased efficiency programme set by BA, has been accepted by BASSA, part of the Transport and General Workers' Union.

BA said that provided the proposals met the 42 million pounds target in a way acceptable to all parties involved, it would then seek a process to move things forward jointly with BASSA and Cabin Crew 89, the second cabin crew union.
However, industry sources said the union did not expect to have the proposals ready until Tuesday or Wednesday.
The union declined to comment, but confirmed that the proposals were still not ready.
"At the moment we are still working on the proposals and we are hoping to have these ready shortly," said a spokeswoman. "They are complicated and we want them to be meaningful."

The dispute over the restructuring programme led to a 72-hour strike by cabin crew earlier in the month, an action that Ayling had said cost the company "tens of millions of pounds." ($ = 0.595 British Pounds)
